elements.content: Zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) are a large subgroup of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs). The synthesis of ZIF phases showing a yqt-type framework by the reaction of methylimidazole (Hmim) with a zinc salt in an aqueous solution using different zinc salts like acetates, nitrates, chlorides, fluorides, bromides, iodides, and sulfates yields different morphologies and products: Zn3mim5XH2O·nH2O with X = Br, Cl and α-Zn3mim5X with X = F, OH. By thermal dehydration of the hydrated ZIF phases, a series of isostructural compounds, α-Zn3mim5X with X = Br, Cl, F, or OH, were obtained. The products were characterized by X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) and vibrational (IR) and two-dimensional (2D) solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy. In all structures, zinc exhibits tetrahedral coordination and forms a yqt net. Inorganic anions are incorporated into this net as Zn–X–Zn bridges and show a major impact on the reversible de- and rehydration behavior, as well as on the thermal expansion. The latter property is mainly governed by bending of the Zn–X–Zn bridge. Within this series, only the chloride-containing phase, showing the strongest anisotropic thermal expansion, exhibits two polymorphs: α- and β-Zn3mim5Cl, the α-form showing a bent and the β-form showing a linear Zn–X–Zn bridge.

The inorganic anions, incorporated into the yqt-type net as Zn−X−Zn bridges show a major impact on the reversible de- and rehydration behavior, the crystal morphology, as well as thermal expansion.

elements.content: Zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) are a large subgroup of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), also sometimes referred to as metal–azolate frameworks with high stability, e.g., toward water. The connection of four methylimidazolate anions to a zinc atom can be described by complex chemistry. Synthetically, the materials are obtained by salt–salt interaction. They find applications in catalysis, chromatography, gas separation, storage, and biomedicine. Their name is derived from their structural relationship to zeolites, as a metal ion like silicon and aluminum in zeolites is tetrahedrally coordinated. Also, the coordinating linker molecules exhibit the same bond angle found for the bridging oxygen atoms in the zeolite structures. Often, the metal centers are zinc and cobalt, but compounds using boron, lithium, and copper; lithium and aluminum; cadmium; or magnesium are also documented. The imidazolate backbone can be functionalized, leading to more than 150 different materials. First reports about metal salts formed with imidazolates were found in the 1950s, even going back to the 1930s.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) are a large subgroup of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), also sometimes referred to as metal-azolate frameworks with high stability, e.g., toward water. The connection of four methylimidazolate anions to a zinc atom can be described by complex chemistry. Synthetically, the materials are obtained by salt-salt interaction. They find applications in catalysis, chromatography, gas separation, storage, and biomedicine. Their name is derived from their structural relationship to zeolites, as a metal ion like silicon and aluminum in zeolites is tetrahedrally coordinated. Also, the coordinating linker molecules exhibit the same bond angle found for the bridging oxygen atoms in the zeolite structures. Often, the metal centers are zinc and cobalt, but compounds using boron, lithium, and copper; lithium and aluminum; cadmium; or magnesium are also documented. The imidazolate backbone can be functionalized, leading to more than 150 different materials. First reports about metal salts formed with imidazolates were found in the 1950s, even going back to the 1930s.

elements.content: ZIF-8 is the most investigated material of this family. The zinc atom is coordinated by four 2-methylimidazolate anions (mim) forming a topology with sodalite-like cages (SOD net) with a diameter of 11.6 Å and window sizes of about 3.4 Å. It was first described in 2006 with several other ZIFs with various linkers. Similar to ZIFs with other linkers, ZIF-8 has several polymorphs with the same composition, but different underlying nets. Unlike ZIFs with imidazole and benzimidazole, where polymorphs were found rather instantaneously (e.g., ZIF-1, ZIF-2, and ZIF-4 for zinc imidazolate and ZIF-7 and ZIF-11, respectively), it took some time to find polymorphs of ZIF-8. In 2011, the crystal structure of ZIF-8dia was published, which has a distorted diamond-like underlying net. The structure of ZIF-8kat, named after one of the investigators, was discovered in 2015 during in situ X-ray diffraction monitoring of liquid-assisted grinding experiments and the product was described as metastable. However, the powder pattern of ZIF-8kat was already reported in 2013 as the result of microwave-assisted syntheses.

elements.content: ZIF-L was described in 2013, Here, the Zn/mim ratio is not 1:2, but 1:2.5, leading to layers containing half sodalite cages and a leaflike morphology. The L stands for leaf. The associated powder pattern can be found in earlier publications. There are several compounds mentioned in the literature obtained by mixed-linker approaches, where methylimidazole is not the only molecule linking the zinc atoms. Most notable are ZIF-60 and ZIF-61 with imidazole as the second linker, yielding materials with MER (merlinoite) and zni (zinc imidazolate) nets. Others are ZIF-300, ZIF-301, and ZIF-302 with 5-BrBIm, 5-ClBIm, and 5-MeBIm (5 bromobenzimdazole, 5-chlorobenzimidazole, and 5-methylbenzimidazole), respectively. They all form a CHA-related net. ZIF-408, ZIF-486, and ZIF-414 are obtained with the use of up to three different linkers.

elements.content: A rather peculiar material is ZIF-CO3-1, where zinc atoms are not only linked by methylimidazolate but also by carbonate anions, forming a mog net (moganite). While the methylimidazolate linkers connect two zinc atoms, the carbonate anions link four different zinc atoms. The structure was first described in 2015 by Basnayake et al. In 2020, this material was found in ball-milling experiments and its crystal structure was determined again. Recently, we described a material where zinc atoms are not only bridged by methylimidazolate, but by chloride ions. ZIF-yqt anhydrous (Zn3mim5Cl) can be hydrated (Zn3mim5ClH2O·nH2O, with n = 0.74) leading to a Zn–Cl/H2O bridge. The underlying net is yqt, first found during syntheses using cadmium and methylimidazole and is a derivation of two interpenetrated tfa-c nets, which are connected via a disordered methylimidazolate group. In ZIF-yqt hydrate and anhydrous, this disordered methylimidazolate group is replaced by chloride and water. Recently, another material with the same underlying net was published, with hydroxide instead of chloride bridging the zinc atoms forming Zn3mim5OH, which was used as a precursor for electrocatalysts. It took some time and electron diffraction methods to find the crystal structure of this material, although it was already mentioned by Tanaka et al. in 2012 during a variation of the zinc nitrate-to-linker ratio for the experiment with a 1:4:2228 composition (with 2228 being the molar ratio of water with respect to the zinc source). The same structure was also found during microwave-assisted experiments for a metal-to-linker ratio of 1:2; however, the water-to-zinc ratio was not mentioned. Butova et al. tried to index the cell, but due to an impurity of ZIF-CO3-1, the structural determination was not successful.

elements.content: In this study, we present the modification of the yqt lattice by halide substitution, which leads to an expansion of the known compounds Zn3mim5Cl·nH2O and Zn3mim5OH toward an entire family of new yqt-type ZIF compounds with the general formula Zn3mim5X with X = Br, Cl, F/OH, and OH. We also systematically study the impact of the halide on the thermal properties and the crystal morphology. Br- and Cl-containing compounds exhibit a reversible de- and rehydration behavior, the chloride-substituted compound having the most pronounced hydration behavior and the strongest anisotropic thermal expansion, leading to two polymorphs of the anhydrous yqt-type ZIF phase. The temperature-dependent anisotropic lattice expansion is governed by bending of the Zn–X–Zn bridges. We furthermore present for the first time an in-depth study on the interactions among methylimidazolate anions within the yqt lattice using 2D solid-state NMR. The impact of zinc salts used on the resulting crystal morphology in the synthesis of the electrocatalytically active Zn3mim5OH is investigated systematically.

We also systematically study the impact of the halide on the thermal properties and the crystal morphology. Br- and Cl-containing compounds exhibit a reversible de- and rehydration behavior, the chloride-substituted compound having the most pronounced hydration behavior and the strongest anisotropic thermal expansion, leading to two polymorphs of the anhydrous yqt-type ZIF phase. elements.content: For synthesis, zinc chloride (Alfa Aesar), zinc bromide (MERCK), zinc fluoride tetrahydrate, zinc iodide (Acros Organics), zinc acetate dihydrate (Fluka), 2-methylimidazole (Acros Organics/Merck) were used, and for analysis, nitric acid, silver nitrate (Sigma Aldrich), acetic acid (Merck), and calcium acetate hydrate (Merck) were used.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Chemicals and Syntheses

For synthesis, zinc chloride (Alfa Aesar), zinc bromide (MERCK), zinc fluoride tetrahydrate, zinc iodide (Acros Organics), zinc acetate dihydrate (Fluka), 2-methylimidazole (Acros Organics/Merck) were used, and for analysis, nitric acid, silver nitrate (Sigma Aldrich), acetic acid (Merck), and calcium acetate hydrate (Merck) were used.

elements.content: In a typical synthesis, 0.699 g (5.13 mmol) of zinc chloride and 1.684 g (20.51 mmol) of 2-methylimidazole were each dissolved in 45 mL of deionized water, giving a molar ratio of 1:4:2000 for zinc, 2-methylimodazole, and water. The investigated range of molar ratios was 1:x:y with 3 ≤ x ≤ 8 and 400 ≤ y ≤ 2400. Both solutions were mixed at room temperature and stirred for several hours until a white, milky suspension is formed. The syntheses were carried out in closed vessels to prevent the formation of ZIF-CO3-1. After centrifugation at 10000 rpm for 5 min, the resulting solid was washed three times with water and centrifuged again. Afterwards, the product was dried in a vacuum oven at 50 °C for 12 h (yield: 1.100 g). Syntheses with zinc fluoride and zinc bromide were conducted similarly. For the successful synthesis with zinc iodide, both solutions were heated to 50 °C prior to mixing and kept at this temperature after mixing to prevent the formation of an amorphous product.

elements.content: The phase composition was analyzed using CHN elemental analyses with an Unicube (Elementar) analyzer. For the determination of the amount of Cl and Br in the respective samples via gravimetric measurement, about 900 mg of the sample was dissolved in HNO3 and subsequently AgCl and AgBr precipitated using AgNO3. The silver salts were centrifuged, washed several times with water, and dried overnight in a vacuum oven at 50 °C. For the determination of the fluoride content, the precipitation method with calcium was used. Approximately 800 mg of the fluoride-containing sample were dissolved in diluted acetic acid. After the addition of calcium acetate in acetic acid, the precipitate was collected via centrifugation and washed several times with water. Afterward, the sample was dried at 50 °C in vacuum for 12 h. The Zn content was derived from thermal analyses conducted with a thermogravimetric analyzer 2950 (TA Instruments) with heating rates of 2 and 5 K/min up to a temperature of 700 °C. At 700 °C, the sample was completely oxidized and only ZnO was left. From the remaining mass, the original zinc content can be calculated. DSC measurements of anhydrous Zn3(mim)5Cl were conducted on a DSC 214 Polyma (Netzsch, 40 mL/min protective, 60 mL/min purging N2 gas). The sample was first dehydrated on a heating plate at 200 °C in an argon-filled glovebox for ∼12 h, weighed (24.8 mg), and finally filled into an aluminum crucible, which was sealed by cold welding with an aluminum cap. The cap was pierced, and a crucible was set into the DSC sample chamber (contact with air during transfer for ∼30 s). An empty, pierced aluminum crucible was used as reference. The sample was cycled between −150 and 225 °C with heating and cooling rates of 2 and 10 K/min, respectively. In the case of the 2 K/min rate, the sample signal was corrected by subtracting the DSC curve of an empty crucible. Scanning electron microscopy measurements were carried out with a Carl-Zeiss Gemini Ultra 55, where an acceleration voltage of 1 kV and a working distance of 5 cm were used. Infrared spectra were measured with a JASCO 4100 IR spectrometer equipped with a PIKE GladiATR unit in a range between 400 and 4000 cm–1 with a resolution of 2 cm–1. Each spectrum is an accumulation of 16 scans. X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) patterns were collected with a Panalytical Empyrean diffractometer (Cu-Kα radiation, β-Ni filter) with a spinner setup in the range of 2θ = 2–50° with a step size of 0.02° and an exposure time of 5 s per step. The dehydration/rehydration experiments were carried out with the same instrument equipped with an Anton Paar CHC+ chamber with z-axis scan in a range of 2θ = 14–15.8° with a step size of 0.0066° and an exposure time of 10.2 s per step. The humidity of the gas flow was adjusted with the help of a modulated humidity Generator from Pro Umid. The dehydration was carried out at 90 °C with a relative humidity of 5%, and the rehydration was carried out at 35 °C with relative humidities between 15 and 50%. Nitrogen sorption isotherms were recorded with a Micromeritics ASAP 2010 instrument. BET areas were calculated according to the recommendations from IUPAC and Rouquerol et al.

elements.content: Solid-state NMR spectra were recorded on an Agilent DD2 500WB spectrometer (11.7 T) with resonance frequencies of 499.86 and 125.70 MHz for 1H and 13C, respectively. Samples were packed into a 1.6 mm zirconia rotor under ambient conditions. 1H spectra were recorded at a MAS rate of 40 kHz using the DEPTH sequence for background suppression, starting with a π/2 pulse of 2.5 μs followed by two π pulses of 5 μs phase cycled according to a combined “EXORCYCLE” and “CYCLOPS” scheme. A total of 16 scans were recorded, and recycle delays were set to 5 times the 1H longitudinal relaxation time. 13C CP spectra were recorded at a MAS rate of 15 kHz. After a π/2 pulse of 2.5 ms on 1H, the 1H RF was ramped from 79 to 100 kHz, while the RF on 13C was kept constant at 74 kHz during a contact time of 1 ms. 100 kHz spinal-64 decoupling was applied on 1H during acquisition. Recycle delays were set to 4 s, and 5600–20000 scans were recorded depending on the sample. 1H–13C heteronuclear correlation (HETCOR) spectra were acquired at a MAS rate of 30 kHz. After a π/2 pulse of 2.5 μs on 1H, the 1H RF was ramped from 94 to 114 kHz, while the RF on 13C was kept constant at 54 kHz for a contact time of 5 ms. A total of 160 increments during the evolution period were recorded, while applying 100 kHz FSLG decoupling. 100 kHz spinal-64 decoupling was applied on 1H during acquisition. A total of 104 scans were accumulated in every increment with a recycle delay of 4.4 s. All chemical shifts were referenced to sodium 3-(trimethylsilyl)-1-propanesulfonate (DSS). No line-broadening was applied.

elements.content: XRPD patterns for phase identification were collected at room temperature on a laboratory powder diffractometer in Debye–Scherrer geometry (Stadi P-diffractometer (Stoe), Cu-Kα1 radiation from primary Ge(111)-Johann-type monochromator, triple array of Mythen 1 K detectors (Dectris)). The samples were sealed in 0.7 mm diameter borosilicate glass capillaries (Hilgenberg glass no. 0140), which were spun during the measurements. Each pattern was measured in a 2θ range of 1.0–110° applying a total scan time of 30 min. The XRPD pattern for the crystal structure solution was collected using the same device and a total scan time of 20 h. Temperature-dependent XRPD patterns were recorded on the same device. Heating of the capillary was realized using a hot and cool air blower (Cobra 700, Oxford cryosystems). Therefore, the starting material, Zn3mim5Cl­(H2O)·xH2O, was filled in a 0.7 mm borosilicate glass capillary (Hilgenberg glass no. 0140), which was left open on the top and spun during the measurements. The sample was heated in 10 K steps by applying a heating rate of 2 K/min up to a temperature of 225 °C. During each step, an XRPD pattern was recorded by applying a total scan time of 30 min and an isothermal delay time of 5 min prior to the measurements. Afterward, the sample was cooled down in 10 K steps to −150 °C by applying a cooling rate of 2 K/min and XRPD measurements were carried out during the holding periods. The heating and cooling steps were repeated afterward. The program TOPAS 6.0 was used for crystal structure solution and refinement with all details given in the Supporting Information.

elements.content: Syntheses of halide-substituted yqt-type ZIF compounds were carried out in aqueous solutions using the related zinc halide salt, 2-methylimidazole (Hmim), and water in defined ratios. The synthesis relies on using conditions as published by us in an earlier paper. Details on the syntheses conditions can be found in the Supporting Information.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Characterization of Halide-Substituted yqt-Type ZIF Compounds

Syntheses of halide-substituted yqt-type ZIF compounds were carried out in aqueous solutions using the related zinc halide salt, 2-methylimidazole (Hmim), and water in defined ratios. The synthesis relies on using conditions as published by us in an earlier paper. Details on the syntheses conditions can be found in the Supporting Information.

elements.content: The synthesis was performed as described earlier by mixing an aqueous zinc chloride solution with an aqueous methylimidazolate solution and stirring the mixture for several hours. Various Hmim/H2O/ZnCl2 ratios were tested, leading to different products (Supporting Information, Figure S6 and Table S5). Applying a Hmim/H2O/ZnCl2 ratio of 1:4:2000 leads to the formation of the previously described chloride-substituted yqt-type ZIF hydrate with the formula Zn3mim5ClH2O·0.74 H2O, as confirmed by XRPD (, red line), elemental, and thermal analyses (, Supporting Information, Table S10, Figure S11). A short investigation of different molar ratios of zinc halides and methylimidazole revealed that the resulting phases are quite diverse (Supporting Information, Figure S7 and Table S6). The nitrogen sorption isotherm showed no porosity for this material (Supporting Information, Figure S20), which are in line with findings for Zn3mim5OH.

The synthesis was performed as described earlier by mixing an aqueous zinc chloride solution with an aqueous methylimidazolate solution and stirring the mixture for several hours. Various Hmim/H2O/ZnCl2 ratios were tested, leading to different products (Supporting Information, Figure S6 and Table S5). Applying a Hmim/H2O/ZnCl2 ratio of 1:4:2000 leads to the formation of the previously described chloride-substituted yqt-type ZIF hydrate with the formula Zn3mim5ClH2O⋅0.74 H2O, as confirmed by XRPD (, red line), elemental, and thermal analyses (, Supporting Information, Table S10, Figure S11). A short investigation of different molar ratios of zinc halides and methylimidazole revealed that the resulting phases are quite diverse (Supporting Information, Figure S7 and Table S6). The nitrogen sorption isotherm showed no porosity for this material (Supporting Information, Figure S20), which are in line with findings for Zn3mim5OH.

C, H, N, and O contents were determined by EA, zinc contents were determined via TG (Supporting Information, Table S10, Figure S11), and the contents of the halides were measured after precipitation with Ca­(OAc)2 for F and with AgNO3 for Cl and Br, respectively.

The C, H, N, and Zn contents were determined from material synthesized with zinc nitrate.

The synthesis with zinc bromide was conducted with the same zinc–2-methylimidazole–water ratio of 1:4:2000 and yielded a phase showing an almost identical powder pattern (, green line) and the same zeppelin-like crystal morphology as the hydrated Cl phase, without developed faces (a–d). The lengths vary between 2 and 5 μm, with the width varying between 0.5 and 3 μm. The Br phase shows the same morphology as the chloride-containing sample with slightly slimmer crystallites. Some of the particles have a slight S-shaped bent along the main axis. In addition, the tips of the zeppelins are not as developed as their chloride-containing relatives. The phase composition of Zn3mim5BrH2O·0.45 H2O was derived from elemental and thermal analyses (Supporting Information, Table S10, Figure S11) and from the crystal structure refinement (, Supporting Information, Table S3).

elements.content: The synthesis with zinc fluoride tetrahydrate yielded a phase with an XRPD pattern ( black line) comparable to the reported diffraction data of anhydrous Zn3mim5OH or anhydrous Zn3mim5Cl. Therefore, we assumed a phase composition of Zn3mim5F. The determination of the fluoride content by dissolution and subsequent calcium fluoride precipitation, however, yielded only 35% of the expected amount. With respect to the alkaline character of the solution from which the fluoride-substituted yqt-type ZIF phase was synthesized and the similar ionic radii, a partial substitution of fluoride by hydroxide appeared likely. Indeed, EDX analyses of five different spots with two different voltages confirm a ratio of Zn/F/OH of ≈ 3.00: 0.35: 0.65 (Supporting Information, Table S5). An IR band at 525 cm–1, which can be assigned to a Zn-OH mode (Supporting Information, Figure S9), additionally confirms the presence of hydroxide ions in the solid. Elemental and thermal analyses (, Supporting Information, Table S10, Figure S11) indicate a phase composition of Zn3mim5F0.35(OH)0.65. The truncated polyhedron-like crystal morphology, which sometimes appears plate-like with fully developed faces, (e,f) significantly differs from the Cl- and Br-substituted phases. The crystallites of the fluoride-containing phase have diameters between 1 and 2.5 μm and a thickness of approximately 0.5 μm.
elements.clean_text:
Fluoride-Substituted yqt-Type ZIF

The synthesis with zinc fluoride tetrahydrate yielded a phase with an XRPD pattern ( black line) comparable to the reported diffraction data of anhydrous Zn3mim5OH or anhydrous Zn3mim5Cl. Therefore, we assumed a phase composition of Zn3mim5F. The determination of the fluoride content by dissolution and subsequent calcium fluoride precipitation, however, yielded only 35% of the expected amount. With respect to the alkaline character of the solution from which the fluoride-substituted yqt-type ZIF phase was synthesized and the similar ionic radii, a partial substitution of fluoride by hydroxide appeared likely. Indeed, EDX analyses of five different spots with two different voltages confirm a ratio of Zn/F/OH of ~ 3.00: 0.35: 0.65 (Supporting Information, Table S5). An IR band at 525 cm-1, which can be assigned to a Zn-OH mode (Supporting Information, Figure S9), additionally confirms the presence of hydroxide ions in the solid. Elemental and thermal analyses (, Supporting Information, Table S10, Figure S11) indicate a phase composition of Zn3mim5F0.35(OH)0.65. The truncated polyhedron-like crystal morphology, which sometimes appears plate-like with fully developed faces, (e,f) significantly differs from the Cl- and Br-substituted phases. The crystallites of the fluoride-containing phase have diameters between 1 and 2.5 μm and a thickness of approximately 0.5 μm.

elements.content: The synthesis of an iodide-containing material of the yqt-type ZIF family was not successful. The conventional synthesis by mixing zinc iodide and methylimidazole in water at room temperature led to an amorphous phase (, blue line). The amorphous phase seems to be related to the yqt phases since the area with the highest intensity in the 2θ range of 13–17° corresponds to the most intensive reflections of other materials. The SEM micrographs show no well-formed crystallites, but rather small, round particles (g,h).
elements.clean_text:
Iodide-Substituted yqt-Type ZIF

The synthesis of an iodide-containing material of the yqt-type ZIF family was not successful. The conventional synthesis by mixing zinc iodide and methylimidazole in water at room temperature led to an amorphous phase (, blue line). The amorphous phase seems to be related to the yqt phases since the area with the highest intensity in the 2θ range of 13-17° corresponds to the most intensive reflections of other materials. The SEM micrographs show no well-formed crystallites, but rather small, round particles (g,h).

elements.content: The hydroxide-substituted yqt-type ZIF phase, Zn3mim5OH, was synthesized from aqueous solutions using different zinc salts. The use of zinc nitrate hexahydrate and zinc acetate dehydrate with a ratio of 1:2:694 has already been reported to lead to the formation of Zn3mim5OH. In addition, we used zinc iodide and a temperature of 50 °C to obtain this phase. It is possible to use ZnSO4, as well. The obtained XRPD patterns are identical (Supporting Information Figure S8 and Table S7) and exhibit similarities to the reported patterns of anhydrous Zn3mim5OH or anhydrous Zn3mim5Cl. We have employed IR spectroscopy to confirm the presence of hydroxide ions in the lattice, indicated by the band at 525 cm–1, which can be assigned to a Zn–OH mode (Supporting Information Figure S9), and confirmed the Zn3mim5OH phase composition by elemental and thermal analyses (, Supporting Information, Table S10, Figure S11).
elements.clean_text:
Morphological Control of the Hydroxide-Substituted yqt-Type ZIF

The hydroxide-substituted yqt-type ZIF phase, Zn3mim5OH, was synthesized from aqueous solutions using different zinc salts. The use of zinc nitrate hexahydrate and zinc acetate dehydrate with a ratio of 1:2:694 has already been reported to lead to the formation of Zn3mim5OH. In addition, we used zinc iodide and a temperature of 50 °C to obtain this phase. It is possible to use ZnSO4, as well. The obtained XRPD patterns are identical (Supporting Information Figure S8 and Table S7) and exhibit similarities to the reported patterns of anhydrous Zn3mim5OH or anhydrous Zn3mim5Cl. We have employed IR spectroscopy to confirm the presence of hydroxide ions in the lattice, indicated by the band at 525 cm-1, which can be assigned to a Zn-OH mode (Supporting Information Figure S9), and confirmed the Zn3mim5OH phase composition by elemental and thermal analyses (, Supporting Information, Table S10, Figure S11).

elements.content: The influence of the anion used in the synthesis on the crystal morphology is shown in . The synthesis with zinc iodide yields round and slightly elongated crystallites with a rough surface indicating a large number of defects. The particles are up to 2 μm long and around 1 μm wide. In contrast to that, the synthesis with zinc acetate yields flat, flakelike particles with a diameter of 1 μm and a thickness of 0.2 μm. The closest resemblance to the Cl- and Br-containing specimen is achieved when using zinc nitrate. Here, the particles exhibit a flattened zeppelin shape without developed faces. The biggest particles are about 6 μm long, 4 μm wide, and around 3 μm thick. The influence of different anions on the crystallite morphology is well known and was shown for ZIF-8. Here, the crystallites resemble cubes, rhombic dodecahedra, and geometrical mixtures of both forming truncated rhombic dodecahedra. The morphology of ZIF-8dia can be changed using different additives. Depending on whether sodium acetate, ammonia solution, or acetic acid is used, the crystallites look like hexagonal plates, elongated hexagonal plates, or exhibit a flakelike morphology, respectively.

elements.content: The compositional analyses of the halide and hydroxide-substituted yqt-type ZIF phases indicated that anhydrous compounds were obtained for the hydroxide and mixed hydroxide–fluoride phases and that syntheses yielded hydrates for the chloride and bromide phases. This was further confirmed by IR spectroscopy and thermal analyses, as described in detail below.
elements.clean_text:
Hydration States of the As-Synthesized, Halide-Substituted yqt-Type ZIF Phases

The compositional analyses of the halide and hydroxide-substituted yqt-type ZIF phases indicated that anhydrous compounds were obtained for the hydroxide and mixed hydroxide-fluoride phases and that syntheses yielded hydrates for the chloride and bromide phases. This was further confirmed by IR spectroscopy and thermal analyses, as described in detail below.

elements.content: The halide-substituted yqt-type ZIF phases exhibit similar IR spectra (Supporting Information, Figure S9) with a tentative band assignment given in our previous work and in the Supporting Information (Table S9). The hydrated Cl and Br phases show two bands in the range of the OH-bending modes (1615 cm–1), while the anhydrous F- and OH-containing compounds exhibit only one band. This correlates with the fact that in the Cl and Br phase H2O is incorporated in the structure and some additional water is present in the framework voids, whereas the F- and OH-substituted compounds contain only one hydroxide species, leading to only one band. The imidazolate ring stretching bands and in-plane bending bands are the same for all materials (1490 −1460 and 1304–920 cm–1, respectively). The band at 930 cm–1 is only present in F and OH phases and can be assigned to OH vibrations. The greatest difference between the spectra can be found in the region of the imidazolate out-of-plane bending between 800 and 600 cm–1. The hydrated Cl and Br samples have two distinct bands at 789 and 760 cm–1, while the dehydrated OH and F materials exhibit two overlapping bands at 769 and 752 cm–1. These vibrational changes result from different sterical hindrances. When the Cl and Br phases are dried at 100 °C, cooled to room temperature in vacuum, and then measured under a dynamic Ar atmosphere, the band positions coincide with the band positions of Zn3mim5OH (Supporting Information Figure S10). The asymmetric Zn–O stretching at 520 cm–1 is only present in samples with distinct OH groups. In the F-containing sample, this band has approximately 70% of the intensity of pure Zn3mim5OH samples, showing that the F-containing sample contains OH groups, as well. There is an additional band at 460 cm–1, which we tentatively attribute to a Zn–F band. The band at 420 cm–1 is strongly visible for all materials and is commonly attributed to the Zn–N stretching mode.
elements.clean_text:
IR Spectroscopy

The halide-substituted yqt-type ZIF phases exhibit similar IR spectra (Supporting Information, Figure S9) with a tentative band assignment given in our previous work and in the Supporting Information (Table S9). The hydrated Cl and Br phases show two bands in the range of the OH-bending modes (1615 cm-1), while the anhydrous F- and OH-containing compounds exhibit only one band. This correlates with the fact that in the Cl and Br phase H2O is incorporated in the structure and some additional water is present in the framework voids, whereas the F- and OH-substituted compounds contain only one hydroxide species, leading to only one band. The imidazolate ring stretching bands and in-plane bending bands are the same for all materials (1490 -1460 and 1304-920 cm-1, respectively). The band at 930 cm-1 is only present in F and OH phases and can be assigned to OH vibrations. The greatest difference between the spectra can be found in the region of the imidazolate out-of-plane bending between 800 and 600 cm-1. The hydrated Cl and Br samples have two distinct bands at 789 and 760 cm-1, while the dehydrated OH and F materials exhibit two overlapping bands at 769 and 752 cm-1. These vibrational changes result from different sterical hindrances. When the Cl and Br phases are dried at 100 °C, cooled to room temperature in vacuum, and then measured under a dynamic Ar atmosphere, the band positions coincide with the band positions of Zn3mim5OH (Supporting Information Figure S10). The asymmetric Zn-O stretching at 520 cm-1 is only present in samples with distinct OH groups. In the F-containing sample, this band has approximately 70% of the intensity of pure Zn3mim5OH samples, showing that the F-containing sample contains OH groups, as well. There is an additional band at 460 cm-1, which we tentatively attribute to a Zn-F band. The band at 420 cm-1 is strongly visible for all materials and is commonly attributed to the Zn-N stretching mode.

elements.content: The presence of water incorporated into the yqt-network of the Cl- and Br-containing phases is additionally confirmed by thermal analyses. After a small, initial mass loss (<2 wt %) caused by insignificant amounts of adsorbed solvent, only the Cl- and Br-yqt-type ZIF compounds exhibit a well-defined mass loss step between 90 and 100 °C (Supporting Information, Figure S11a, Table S10) attributed to the release of hydrate water. These phases also show a second mass loss step starting at around 230 °C due to the hydrolysis of the halide anions in the dynamic atmosphere, before the combustion of the 2-methylimidazolate starts at 320 °C for the Br phase and 360 °C for the Cl phase, respectively. In contrast, the F- and OH-substituted yqt-type ZIF compounds show only one mass loss step starting at 380 °C for the OH phase and at 400 °C for the F/OH phase (Supporting Information Figure S10b). Thus, the F- and OH-substituted yqt-type compounds exhibit higher thermal stability than their Cl- and Br-substituted counterparts.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Decomposition

The presence of water incorporated into the yqt-network of the Cl- and Br-containing phases is additionally confirmed by thermal analyses. After a small, initial mass loss (<2 wt %) caused by insignificant amounts of adsorbed solvent, only the Cl- and Br-yqt-type ZIF compounds exhibit a well-defined mass loss step between 90 and 100 °C (Supporting Information, Figure S11a, Table S10) attributed to the release of hydrate water. These phases also show a second mass loss step starting at around 230 °C due to the hydrolysis of the halide anions in the dynamic atmosphere, before the combustion of the 2-methylimidazolate starts at 320 °C for the Br phase and 360 °C for the Cl phase, respectively. In contrast, the F- and OH-substituted yqt-type ZIF compounds show only one mass loss step starting at 380 °C for the OH phase and at 400 °C for the F/OH phase (Supporting Information Figure S10b). Thus, the F- and OH-substituted yqt-type compounds exhibit higher thermal stability than their Cl- and Br-substituted counterparts.

elements.content: The crystal structure analysis of the Br-substituted, hydrated yqt-type ZIF compound, Zn3mim5BrH2O·0.45H2O, revealed it to be isostructural to the previously described hydrated, Cl-containing yqt-type ZIF phase, Zn3mim5ClH2O·0.74H2O (Supporting Information Figure S4, Tables S2–S4). The unit cell dimensions of both compounds are almost identical (), which seems to be counterintuitive due to the larger ionic radius of the bromide anion. However, the bromide phase contains significantly less hydrate water (0.45 molecules) in the voids of the yqt-network than the related Cl compound (0.74 molecules), which has been demonstrated to have a major impact on the lattice parameters. Like the corresponding Cl phase, Zn3mim5BrH2O·0.45H2O can be de- and rehydrated reversibly (Figure S12). The dehydration was conducted at 90 °C with a gas flow of 150 mL/min with 5% relative humidity, while the rehydration took place at 35 °C with a relative humidity of 25%. The Cl phase is dehydrated faster than the Br phase (approx. 980 s compared to 1200 s, respectively), while the Br phase rehydrates faster than the Cl phase (Figure S13). The time for rehydration strongly depends on relative humidity. Increasing the relative humidity from 15 to 50% lowers the rehydration time of the Br phase from more than 2000 s to below 300 s.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Comparison of Hydrated Cl- and Br-Substituted yqt-Type ZIF Phases

The crystal structure analysis of the Br-substituted, hydrated yqt-type ZIF compound, Zn3mim5BrH2O⋅0.45H2O, revealed it to be isostructural to the previously described hydrated, Cl-containing yqt-type ZIF phase, Zn3mim5ClH2O⋅0.74H2O (Supporting Information Figure S4, Tables S2-S4). The unit cell dimensions of both compounds are almost identical (), which seems to be counterintuitive due to the larger ionic radius of the bromide anion. However, the bromide phase contains significantly less hydrate water (0.45 molecules) in the voids of the yqt-network than the related Cl compound (0.74 molecules), which has been demonstrated to have a major impact on the lattice parameters. Like the corresponding Cl phase, Zn3mim5BrH2O⋅0.45H2O can be de- and rehydrated reversibly (Figure S12). The dehydration was conducted at 90 °C with a gas flow of 150 mL/min with 5% relative humidity, while the rehydration took place at 35 °C with a relative humidity of 25%. The Cl phase is dehydrated faster than the Br phase (approx. 980 s compared to 1200 s, respectively), while the Br phase rehydrates faster than the Cl phase (Figure S13). The time for rehydration strongly depends on relative humidity. Increasing the relative humidity from 15 to 50% lowers the rehydration time of the Br phase from more than 2000 s to below 300 s.

As Zn3mim5ClH2O·0.74H2O and Zn3mim5BrH2O·0.45H2O can be easily dehydrated, we studied the impact of the inorganic anion, X, on the yqt-type network in anhydrous Zn3mim5X compounds, with X = F, Br, Cl, or OH. Initially, the previously published structure of anhydrous Zn3mim5Cl was used as a starting model to refine the crystal structures of the Br, OH, and F/OH analogues. The XRPD patterns of these phases, however, could not be described by the unit cell of the anhydrous chloride compound with C 2/ c space group symmetry. Instead, these patterns were indexed by a unit cell of the same metric but with space group P 21/ c (). To reevaluate the already published structure of Zn3mim5Cl, which was solved from in situ XRPD data collected at 200 °C, we dehydrated Zn3mim5ClH2O·0.74H2O in a TG/DTA in a dry argon stream at 225 °C, subsequently cooled down the sample to room temperature, and instantaneously collected the XRPD pattern (a). The XRPD patterns of anhydrous Zn3mim5Cl collected at 200 °C (a, red pattern) and 25 °C (blue pattern) are not identical. The pattern collected at room temperature exhibits additional reflections that can be indexed as 100, 1̅02, and 012. In addition, there is a pronounced separation of overlapping reflections like 122 and 3̅1̅1 (a, gray-highlighted background). Therefore, the pattern can be indexed by the same unit cell metrics but with space group P 21/ c . Thus, there are two polymorphs of anhydrous Zn3mim5Cl: a room-temperature modification, referred to as α-Zn3mim5Cl and a high-temperature polymorph, β-Zn3mim5Cl, with the latter one being previously reported. All patterns of anhydrous Zn3mim5X compounds, with X = F, Br, Cl, or OH are almost identical and can be indexed with the P 21/ c unit cell, as indicated by the presence of the 012 reflection (b) and can be therefore denoted as α-Zn3mim5X, with X = F, Br, Cl, or OH.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Chemistry of Anhydrous Zn3mim5X, with X = F, Br, Cl, or OH

As Zn3mim5ClH2O⋅0.74H2O and Zn3mim5BrH2O⋅0.45H2O can be easily dehydrated, we studied the impact of the inorganic anion, X, on the yqt-type network in anhydrous Zn3mim5X compounds, with X = F, Br, Cl, or OH. Initially, the previously published structure of anhydrous Zn3mim5Cl was used as a starting model to refine the crystal structures of the Br, OH, and F/OH analogues. The XRPD patterns of these phases, however, could not be described by the unit cell of the anhydrous chloride compound with  C 2/ c  space group symmetry. Instead, these patterns were indexed by a unit cell of the same metric but with space group  P 21/ c  (). To reevaluate the already published structure of Zn3mim5Cl, which was solved from in situ XRPD data collected at 200 °C, we dehydrated Zn3mim5ClH2O⋅0.74H2O in a TG/DTA in a dry argon stream at 225 °C, subsequently cooled down the sample to room temperature, and instantaneously collected the XRPD pattern (a). The XRPD patterns of anhydrous Zn3mim5Cl collected at 200 °C (a, red pattern) and 25 °C (blue pattern) are not identical. The pattern collected at room temperature exhibits additional reflections that can be indexed as 100, 1̅02, and 012. In addition, there is a pronounced separation of overlapping reflections like 122 and 3̅1̅1 (a, gray-highlighted background). Therefore, the pattern can be indexed by the same unit cell metrics but with space group  P 21/ c . Thus, there are two polymorphs of anhydrous Zn3mim5Cl: a room-temperature modification, referred to as α-Zn3mim5Cl and a high-temperature polymorph, β-Zn3mim5Cl, with the latter one being previously reported. All patterns of anhydrous Zn3mim5X compounds, with X = F, Br, Cl, or OH are almost identical and can be indexed with the  P 21/ c  unit cell, as indicated by the presence of the 012 reflection (b) and can be therefore denoted as α-Zn3mim5X, with X = F, Br, Cl, or OH.

(b) Comparison of the XRPD of α-Zn3mim5X with X = Br, Cl, F or OH collected at 25 °C.

In the crystal structures of α-Zn3mim5X, with X = F, Br, Cl, or OH, all atoms are situated on general positions (Supporting Information Table S3). There are three symmetrically independent tetrahedrally coordinated zinc cations. Zn1 is coordinated exclusively by 2-methylimidazolate anions (a), whereas Zn2 and Zn3 are coordinated by three 2-methylimidazolate anions and the inorganic anion, X, that bridges both cations (b). Two interpenetrated tfa-c nets, connected via Zn2–X–Zn3 bridges and thus forming a yqt1-type net were identified as underlying macroscopic structural motif (c). Therefore, the crystal structures of α- and β-Zn3mim5Cl exhibit strong similarities. While in the β-form, Zn1 is situated on a twofold rotation axis and Cl is located on an inversion center, these ions move to general positions after the transition from β- to α-Zn3mim5Cl. As a consequence, the zinc cations situated in the coordination sphere of the chloride anion become symmetrically independent and the linear Zn–Cl–Zn bridge tilts. In fact, there is a direct group–subgroup relation between the β- (space group C 2/ c ) and the α-form (space group P 21/ c ) accompanied by a shift of the unit cell origin by [1/4, 1/4, 0] (Supporting Information Figure S14).

elements.content: Although the inorganic anion X is only a minor component in α-Zn3mim5X phases, it significantly influences the crystal structure, as well as the thermal properties. From X = F/OH to X = Br, the increase in the unit cell volume from 2458.7(2) to 2536.2(11) Å3 corresponds to the increasing ionic radii along this row (). The trend of the lattice parameters, however, does not exhibit any linear dependence on the radius of X. While the lengths of the a- and b-axes homogenously increase upon substituting X with larger anions, the lengths of the c-axis only increase from F/OH to Cl. When Cl is substituted by Br, this axis shortens significantly from 14.2065(4) to 14.090(3) Å (). The unusual change in the c-lattice parameter is associated with a shift of the monoclinic unit cell metric toward a trigonal unit cell. For all compounds, the β-angle is close to 120° and for α-Zn3mim5Br, a and c become almost identical. However, it must be noted that a LeBail fit with triangular symmetry of the related XRPD pattern did not yield satisfying results, thus the monoclinic unit space group symmetry of α-Zn3mim5Br is confirmed. The substitution of X by different halide and hydroxide anions also impacts the Zn2–X–Zn3 bridge, which is crucial for the interpenetration of the tfa-nets in the structure (b,c). For compounds with X = F/OH, OH, and Cl, the bridge is asymmetric, i.e., d­(Zn2-X) ≠ d­(Zn3-X) and the Zn2–X–Zn3 bridge is tilted with angles significantly lower than 180 °C (). In the structure of the Br phase, however, the Zn2–X–Zn3 bridge is almost symmetric and linear, which additionally points to the trigonal pseudo-symmetry of this phase.

elements.content: Heating and cooling of the α-Zn3mim5X phases also show unexpected behavior along the row X = F/OH, OH, Cl, and Br. While the phases with X = F/OH, OH, and Br do not show any phase transition in the temperature range between 123 and 498 K, α-Zn3mim5Cl reversibly transforms into the β-form at 373–393 K (Supporting Information Figures S15 and S16). The transition from α- into β-Zn3mim5Cl can best be described as a second-order phase transition, due to the following aspects: (i) There is a direct group–subgroup relation between the structures of both polymorphs (Supporting Information Figure S14). (ii) During the transition from β- into α-Zn3mim5Cl, new reflections like 100 and 012 gradually appear and the splitting of the overlapping 112 and 3̅1̅1 reflections evolves slowly (Supporting Information Figure S17). (iii) The evolution of the lattice parameter during heating and cooling does not show any singularity around the phase transition (c, gray-highlighted area). (iv) There are no distinct peaks, except background effects in the DSC curves recorded during heating and cooling of anhydrous Zn3mim5Cl (Supporting Information Figure S18).

While the phases with X = F/OH, OH, and Br do not show any phase transition in the temperature range between 123 and 498 K, α-Zn3mim5Cl reversibly transforms into the β-form at 373-393 K (Supporting Information Figures S15 and S16). The transition from α- into β-Zn3mim5Cl can best be described as a second-order phase transition, due to the following aspects: (i) There is a direct group-subgroup relation between the structures of both polymorphs (Supporting Information Figure S14). (ii) During the transition from β- into α-Zn3mim5Cl, new reflections like 100 and 012 gradually appear and the splitting of the overlapping 112 and 3̅1̅1 reflections evolves slowly (Supporting Information Figure S17). (iii) The evolution of the lattice parameter during heating and cooling does not show any singularity around the phase transition (c, gray-highlighted area). (iv) There are no distinct peaks, except background effects in the DSC curves recorded during heating and cooling of anhydrous Zn3mim5Cl (Supporting Information Figure S18).

elements.content: However, it should be noted that the aforementioned reasons do not exclude a very slowly occurring first-order phase transition between α- and β-Zn3mim5Cl. Interestingly, the transition between an α- and a β-form was only observed for the chloride phase. The fluoride-, hydroxide-, or the bromide-substituted, anhydrous yqt-type ZIF does not exhibit an α-β-transition between 120 and 498 K (Supporting Information Figures S15 and S16). This may be explained by the size and charge density of the inorganic anion: While fluoride and hydroxide seem too small to fill the void within the interpenetrated tfa networks with a linear Zn–X–Zn bridge, chloride has the proper size for a linear bridge. Nevertheless, due to their electronic configuration, these anions still prefer a tetrahedral coordination sphere (Supporting Information, Figure S19), which could be the driving force of the α–β-phase transition. In contrast, bromide is large and has a significantly lower charge density, which allows an almost linear, symmetrical Zn–Br–Zn bridge () and directs the lattice toward trigonal pseudo-symmetry. The Zn–Br bond shows enough flexibility to allow for a monoclinic distortion. The temperature-dependent expansion and contraction of the lattice parameters, which was monitored during heating and cooling cycles between 120 and 498 K (, filled and empty symbols), show anisotropic behavior for all investigated compounds. Upon cooling, both the a- and b-axes show significant contraction (, black and red symbols), between −1 and −2% (), whereas the c*-axes, corresponding to the 001 lattice plane distance, expands upon cooling (, blue symbols) or only shows minor contraction for the Br phase (). For all phases, except the chloride phase, the b-axis shows a higher contraction upon cooling than the a-axis. In the F/OH-substituted phase, this trend is more pronounced than in the pure OH-substituted yqt-type ZIF (a,b). The thermal expansion of the Br-substituted phase reflects the pseudo-trigonal lattice symmetry, as the a- and b-axes show an almost identical expansion behavior. In addition, this phase exhibits the smallest overall thermal expansion (). The expansion of the chloride-substituted phase, however, is outstanding, as it shows the highest volume expansion (), the most pronounced anisotropic thermal expansion with the highest expansion of the c*-axis and the largest contraction of the a-axis upon cooling and a nonlinear thermal behavior of the a-axis (c).

For a more in-depth analyses of the thermal expansion of the α-Zn3mim5X materials, we calculated the thermal expansion coefficients along the orthogonalized principal direction (Supporting Information Table S11) using the PASCAL software. Contraction upon cooling and expansion upon heating occurs along the principal axes X2 and X3 that roughly correspond to [0, 1, 0] and [ 1, 0, 0.2] directions in the unit cells (, blue arrows). These vectors form a plane in which all Zn–X–Zn bridges are located (, red bonds), which show bending, contraction, and elongation upon temperature changes. Thus, the thermal expansion is directed by the Zn–X bonds and therefore by the X-substitution. Perpendicular to this plane, expansion upon cooling occurs in the principal X1 direction corresponding to the [−0.5, 0, −0.8] vector within the unit cell (, red arrows). In this direction, ringlike motifs are present, in which zinc cations are exclusively connected via 2-methylimidazolate anions. These rings are squeezed and elongated upon extension and expansion of the Zn–X–Zn bridges and therefore exhibit a contrary thermal behavior. This leads to a possible explanation of the nonlinear thermal expansion behavior of α-Zn3mim5Cl (c). Upon cooling of the β-form, the lattice starts to contract, while the Zn–Cl–Zn bond is still linear, which creates an internal strain within the ringlike motifs (). As soon as the Zn–Cl–Zn bridge starts to bend during the transition from the β-form to the α-form, the strain is released by a rapid anisotropic contraction and deformation of the ring. After releasing the strain, the thermal expansion decelerates to a rate comparable to the other halide- and hydroxide-substituted yqt-type ZIF compounds (Supporting Information Table S11).
elements.clean_text: For a more in-depth analyses of the thermal expansion of the α-Zn3mim5X materials, we calculated the thermal expansion coefficients along the orthogonalized principal direction (Supporting Information Table S11) using the PASCAL software. Contraction upon cooling and expansion upon heating occurs along the principal axes X2 and X3 that roughly correspond to [0, 1, 0] and [ 1, 0, 0.2] directions in the unit cells (, blue arrows). These vectors form a plane in which all Zn-X-Zn bridges are located (, red bonds), which show bending, contraction, and elongation upon temperature changes. Thus, the thermal expansion is directed by the Zn-X bonds and therefore by the X-substitution. Perpendicular to this plane, expansion upon cooling occurs in the principal X1 direction corresponding to the [-0.5, 0, -0.8] vector within the unit cell (, red arrows). elements.content: The as-synthesized yqt-type ZIF compounds were investigated by different 1H and 13C solid-state NMR spectroscopy techniques. 1D 1H NMR spectra were recorded at a fast magic angle spinning (MAS) rate of 40 kHz for optimum resolution (a). The broad signal at around 2 ppm is attributed to methyl groups. At 5.4 and 7.0 ppm, Zn3mim5BrH2O·nH2O and Zn3mim5ClH2O·nH2O show two distinct resonances of the protons at the aromatic imidazolate carbon positions, α Zn3mim5F1 x (OH) x and α-Zn3mim5OH show only one signal of imidazolate protons. These materials also exhibit a strongly shielded signal at 1.0 ppm. 1H resonances with negative chemical shifts between −0.3 and −1.4 ppm have been found for hydroxyl groups in γ-alumina and in magnesium oxide. The resonance at −1.0 ppm is therefore assigned to the μ2-OH groups bridging two Zn tetrahedra. Signal deconvolution using DMFit yields a relative intensity of these resonances of 1.09 protons (expected: 1.00) for α-Zn3mim5OH and 1.18 for α-Zn3mim5F1–x (OH) x , calculated in relation to the signal of the methyl protons (Table S12). The higher signal ratio of this resonance in α-Zn3mim5F1–x (OH) x indicates a higher OH content in this material than expected, but may be prone to uncertainty due to their large line width. Zn3mim5BrH2O·nH2O and Zn3mim5ClH2O·nH2O, on the other hand, show weak and broad signals at 11.7 ppm corresponding to strongly hydrogen-bonded and deshielded protons from water molecules bridging between the bromide or chloride anion and Zn tetrahedra. Due to their low intensity and broad peak shape, these signals cannot be precisely quantified (Table S12).

Solid-State NMR Spectroscopy

The as-synthesized yqt-type ZIF compounds were investigated by different 1H and 13C solid-state NMR spectroscopy techniques. 1D 1H NMR spectra were recorded at a fast magic angle spinning (MAS) rate of 40 kHz for optimum resolution (a). The broad signal at around 2 ppm is attributed to methyl groups. At 5.4 and 7.0 ppm, Zn3mim5BrH2O⋅nH2O and Zn3mim5ClH2O⋅nH2O show two distinct resonances of the protons at the aromatic imidazolate carbon positions, α Zn3mim5F1 x (OH) x  and α-Zn3mim5OH show only one signal of imidazolate protons. These materials also exhibit a strongly shielded signal at  1.0 ppm. 1H resonances with negative chemical shifts between -0.3 and -1.4 ppm have been found for hydroxyl groups in γ-alumina and in magnesium oxide. The resonance at -1.0 ppm is therefore assigned to the μ2-OH groups bridging two Zn tetrahedra. Signal deconvolution using DMFit yields a relative intensity of these resonances of 1.09 protons (expected: 1.00) for α-Zn3mim5OH and 1.18 for α-Zn3mim5F1-x (OH) x , calculated in relation to the signal of the methyl protons (Table S12). The higher signal ratio of this resonance in α-Zn3mim5F1-x (OH) x  indicates a higher OH content in this material than expected, but may be prone to uncertainty due to their large line width. Zn3mim5BrH2O⋅nH2O and Zn3mim5ClH2O⋅nH2O, on the other hand, show weak and broad signals at 11.7 ppm corresponding to strongly hydrogen-bonded and deshielded protons from water molecules bridging between the bromide or chloride anion and Zn tetrahedra. Due to their low intensity and broad peak shape, these signals cannot be precisely quantified (Table S12).

elements.content: 13C CP NMR spectra (b) show three groups of signals at 11–20, 122–128, and 150−154 ppm, corresponding to carbon atoms of the methyl groups, imidazolate carbon atoms, and the quaternary carbon atoms in the imidazolate moieties. The splitting of the 13C resonances arises from several crystallographically inequivalent imidazolate moieties in the unit cell. The higher number of signals in α-Zn3mim5F1–x (OH) x and α-Zn3mim5OH indicates the lower symmetry of the latter structures, which contain five symmetrically independent imidazolate anions vs 2.5 independent imidazolate anions in the hydrated phases of Zn3mim5BrH2O·nH2O and Zn3mim5ClH2O·nH2O.

elements.content: 1H-13C HETCOR spectra of Zn3mim5BrH2O·nH2O (a) and α-Zn3mim5OH (b) were recorded, representative for the two different crystal structures. A fast MAS rate of 30 kHz and 100 kHz FLSG decoupling on the proton channel during t1 evolution yield a high resolution of the individual proton signals. In Zn3mim5BrH2O·nH2O, the three different methyl groups are visible in the 1H-13C HETCOR spectra at 15.4, 17.3, and 18.1 ppm in a relative intensity of 2:2:1, the resonance at 15.4 ppm being slightly split up into two signals. Cross-correlation of the methyl carbon atoms to 1H signals around 2 ppm allows us to assign the directly bound protons in the methyl group.

elements.content: The weakest 13C methyl resonance at 18.1 ppm can be attributed clearly to mim3 (a, yellow), as this imidazolate is present only once in the unit cell. For the further assignment, we assume that the negative charge of the neighboring OH–/Br– anion may have a weak shielding effect on both 1H and 13C methyl resonances. Mim3 exhibits the longest distance to the OH–/Br– in the unit cell (4.0 Å) and the highest chemical shift. Along these lines, the 13C methyl resonance at 17.3 ppm can then be attributed to mim2 (purple, 2 molecules per unit cell) with a distance of 3.8 Å to H2O/Br– and the resonance at 15.4 ppm to mim1 (green) with a distance of only 3.5 Å. The splitting of this signal may be caused here by the close proximity to either a Br– anion or H2O, with strongly different charge densities. Thus, MAS NMR can elucidate here the local environment in addition to the crystallographic position. Both carbon and protons signals of the imidazolate around 6 ppm show splitting into two resonances. As the two imidazolate carbon atoms in one molecule have different chemical environments, neighboring either a Zn­(mim)3 or a Zn-Br/H2O bridge, they are expected to give rise to two different chemical shifts. NMR data reveal that slight changes in the through-space interactions affect most of the methyl carbon atoms, resulting in four distinguishable peaks, while the resonances of the imidazole carbon atoms are dominated by zinc coordination.

For the further assignment, we assume that the negative charge of the neighboring OH-/Br- anion may have a weak shielding effect on both 1H and 13C methyl resonances. Mim3 exhibits the longest distance to the OH-/Br- in the unit cell (4.0 Å) and the highest chemical shift. Along these lines, the 13C methyl resonance at 17.3 ppm can then be attributed to mim2 (purple, 2 molecules per unit cell) with a distance of 3.8 Å to H2O/Br- and the resonance at 15.4 ppm to mim1 (green) with a distance of only 3.5 Å. The splitting of this signal may be caused here by the close proximity to either a Br- anion or H2O, with strongly different charge densities. Thus, MAS NMR can elucidate here the local environment in addition to the crystallographic position. Both carbon and protons signals of the imidazolate around 6 ppm show splitting into two resonances. As the two imidazolate carbon atoms in one molecule have different chemical environments, neighboring either a Zn(mim)3 or a Zn-Br/H2O bridge, they are expected to give rise to two different chemical shifts. NMR data reveal that slight changes in the through-space interactions affect most of the methyl carbon atoms, resulting in four distinguishable peaks, while the resonances of the imidazole carbon atoms are dominated by zinc coordination.

elements.content: The structure of α-Zn3mim5OH has lower symmetry, leading to more distinct signals for individual crystallographic positions. In the 13C dimension, four methyl positions are visible at 12.5, 14.8, 15.6, and 17.5 ppm with an approximate signal ratio of 1:1:1:2. Cross-peaks with 1H resonances indicate the directly bound protons in the methyl group. Following the reasoning above, we attribute the methyl resonance at 17.5 ppm (purple) to mim1 and mim2 with longer distances of more than 4 Å to the F– anion, and the resonance at 15.6 and 14.8 ppm to mim3 and mim4 (green), with distances of 3.5 and 3.3 Å to F–, respectively. mim5 is again distinguished by a weaker signal at 12.5 ppm (cyan). Only two different quaternary carbon positions Cq can be discerned, reflecting their position at the center of the imidazolate molecules with less interactions to neighboring groups. They are correlated to the three groups of methyl protons around 2 ppm in an intramolecular coupling and to the imidazolate protons around 6 ppm either by intramolecular or by intermolecular interactions with neighboring imidazolate moieties. The aromatic imidazolate carbon positions CHmim are visible at 126.0, 124.9, and 123.9 ppm with an intensity ratio of approximately 2:2:1. Here, the two aromatic carbon positions in mim5 (cyan) have the same chemical shifts, as they are tethered to zinc atoms bound to an OH group each. The carbon atoms in mim1 to mim4 show two different chemical shifts depending on their connection to a Zn­(mim)3 or a Zn­(mim)2OH group (pink and orange). All imidazolate carbon positions couple to the protons at 4.8 ppm, which is an indication of a non-negligible amount of adsorbed water in the structure. In summary, thanks to the high sensitivity of 1H and 13C chemical shifts to the local environment of the observed nuclei, MAS NMR spectra allow us to assign with high resolution the individual crystallographic sites in the two materials. MAS NMR spectroscopy thus adds valuable complementary information to the crystallographic results, which are also useful for further studies on less ordered phases, such as amorphous materials, thin films, or surface effects in ZIF structures.

elements.content: We have introduced and investigated a new family of ZIF compounds with a yqt-type network as macroscopic structural motif, synthesized by precipitation from different zinc salt solutions using 2-methylimidazole. A series of isostructural phases, α-Zn3mim5X with X = Br, Cl, F, or OH, were obtained, and their crystal structures were determined ab initio from laboratory X-ray powder diffraction data. The anion of the zinc salt directs the product formation and morphology, governs capability for reversible hydration, and directs the thermal expansion behavior. In particular, the hydrated zinc 2-methylimidazolate bromide and chloride phases, Zn3mim5Cl/Br­(H2O)·nH2O, show a reversible de- and rehydration behavior, which is not seen in the fluoride- and hydroxide-containing compounds Zn3mim5OH and Zn3mim5F/OH. In the row of the inorganic anions Br, Cl, F, and OH, chloride it situated on a sweet spot for a most versatile structure, as chloride-substituted ZIF phases exhibit the most pronounced hydration behavior and the strongest anisotropic thermal expansion and two polymorphs of the anhydrous yqt-type ZIF phase: α- and β-Zn3mim5Cl. We find that the temperature-dependent anisotropic lattice expansion is mainly governed by bending of the Zn–X–Zn bridges. Well-resolved solid-state NMR spectroscopy allows us to discern the distinct signals of the crystallographically different sites and gives additional information about local structures, shedding light onto interactions between functional groups. In particular, the versatile Zn3mim5Cl­(H2O)·nH2O compounds may find applications in heat storage via water uptake and release or gas adsorption. The selective adsorption of other volatile compounds for separation purposes shall also be investigated in the future. This study further deepens the understanding of the relation between composition, structure, and spectral signatures in ZIFs materials and opens new perspectives for crystal engineering.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

We have introduced and investigated a new family of ZIF compounds with a yqt-type network as macroscopic structural motif, synthesized by precipitation from different zinc salt solutions using 2-methylimidazole. A series of isostructural phases, α-Zn3mim5X with X = Br, Cl, F, or OH, were obtained, and their crystal structures were determined ab initio from laboratory X-ray powder diffraction data. The anion of the zinc salt directs the product formation and morphology, governs capability for reversible hydration, and directs the thermal expansion behavior. In particular, the hydrated zinc 2-methylimidazolate bromide and chloride phases, Zn3mim5Cl/Br(H2O)⋅nH2O, show a reversible de- and rehydration behavior, which is not seen in the fluoride- and hydroxide-containing compounds Zn3mim5OH and Zn3mim5F/OH. In the row of the inorganic anions Br, Cl, F, and OH, chloride it situated on a sweet spot for a most versatile structure, as chloride-substituted ZIF phases exhibit the most pronounced hydration behavior and the strongest anisotropic thermal expansion and two polymorphs of the anhydrous yqt-type ZIF phase: α- and β-Zn3mim5Cl. We find that the temperature-dependent anisotropic lattice expansion is mainly governed by bending of the Zn-X-Zn bridges. Well-resolved solid-state NMR spectroscopy allows us to discern the distinct signals of the crystallographically different sites and gives additional information about local structures, shedding light onto interactions between functional groups. In particular, the versatile Zn3mim5Cl(H2O)⋅nH2O compounds may find applications in heat storage via water uptake and release or gas adsorption. The selective adsorption of other volatile compounds for separation purposes shall also be investigated in the future. This study further deepens the understanding of the relation between composition, structure, and spectral signatures in ZIFs materials and opens new perspectives for crystal engineering.

cln_elements.content:
In a typical synthesis, 0.699 g (5.13 mmol) of zinc chloride and 1.684 g (20.51 mmol) of 2-methylimidazole were each dissolved in 45 mL of deionized water, giving a molar ratio of 1:4:2000 for zinc, 2-methylimodazole, and water. The investigated range of molar ratios was 1:x:y with 3 ≤ x ≤ 8 and 400 ≤ y ≤ 2400. Both solutions were mixed at room temperature and stirred for several hours until a white, milky suspension is formed. The syntheses were carried out in closed vessels to prevent the formation of ZIF-CO3-1. After centrifugation at 10000 rpm for 5 min, the resulting solid was washed three times with water and centrifuged again. Afterwards, the product was dried in a vacuum oven at 50 °C for 12 h (yield: 1.100 g). Syntheses with zinc fluoride and zinc bromide were conducted similarly. For the successful synthesis with zinc iodide, both solutions were heated to 50 °C prior to mixing and kept at this temperature after mixing to prevent the formation of an amorphous product.

Chloride-Substituted yqt-Type ZIF

The synthesis was performed as described earlier by mixing an aqueous zinc chloride solution with an aqueous methylimidazolate solution and stirring the mixture for several hours. Various Hmim/H2O/ZnCl2 ratios were tested, leading to different products (Supporting Information, Figure S6 and Table S5). Applying a Hmim/H2O/ZnCl2 ratio of 1:4:2000 leads to the formation of the previously described chloride-substituted yqt-type ZIF hydrate with the formula Zn3mim5ClH2O·0.74 H2O, as confirmed by XRPD (, red line), elemental, and thermal analyses (, Supporting Information, Table S10, Figure S11). A short investigation of different molar ratios of zinc halides and methylimidazole revealed that the resulting phases are quite diverse (Supporting Information, Figure S7 and Table S6). The nitrogen sorption isotherm showed no porosity for this material (Supporting Information, Figure S20), which are in line with findings for Zn3mim5OH.

Fluoride-Substituted yqt-Type ZIF

The synthesis with zinc fluoride tetrahydrate yielded a phase with an XRPD pattern ( black line) comparable to the reported diffraction data of anhydrous Zn3mim5OH or anhydrous Zn3mim5Cl. Therefore, we assumed a phase composition of Zn3mim5F. The determination of the fluoride content by dissolution and subsequent calcium fluoride precipitation, however, yielded only 35% of the expected amount. With respect to the alkaline character of the solution from which the fluoride-substituted yqt-type ZIF phase was synthesized and the similar ionic radii, a partial substitution of fluoride by hydroxide appeared likely. Indeed, EDX analyses of five different spots with two different voltages confirm a ratio of Zn/F/OH of ≈ 3.00: 0.35: 0.65 (Supporting Information, Table S5). An IR band at 525 cm–1, which can be assigned to a Zn-OH mode (Supporting Information, Figure S9), additionally confirms the presence of hydroxide ions in the solid. Elemental and thermal analyses (, Supporting Information, Table S10, Figure S11) indicate a phase composition of Zn3mim5F0.35(OH)0.65. The truncated polyhedron-like crystal morphology, which sometimes appears plate-like with fully developed faces, (e,f) significantly differs from the Cl- and Br-substituted phases. The crystallites of the fluoride-containing phase have diameters between 1 and 2.5 μm and a thickness of approximately 0.5 μm.

cln_elements.content: However, it should be noted that the aforementioned reasons do not exclude a very slowly occurring first-order phase transition between α- and β-Zn3mim5Cl. Interestingly, the transition between an α- and a β-form was only observed for the chloride phase. The fluoride-, hydroxide-, or the bromide-substituted, anhydrous yqt-type ZIF does not exhibit an α-β-transition between 120 and 498 K (Supporting Information Figures S15 and S16). This may be explained by the size and charge density of the inorganic anion: While fluoride and hydroxide seem too small to fill the void within the interpenetrated tfa networks with a linear Zn–X–Zn bridge, chloride has the proper size for a linear bridge. Nevertheless, due to their electronic configuration, these anions still prefer a tetrahedral coordination sphere (Supporting Information, Figure S19), which could be the driving force of the α–β-phase transition. In contrast, bromide is large and has a significantly lower charge density, which allows an almost linear, symmetrical Zn–Br–Zn bridge () and directs the lattice toward trigonal pseudo-symmetry. The Zn–Br bond shows enough flexibility to allow for a monoclinic distortion. The temperature-dependent expansion and contraction of the lattice parameters, which was monitored during heating and cooling cycles between 120 and 498 K (, filled and empty symbols), show anisotropic behavior for all investigated compounds. Upon cooling, both the a- and b-axes show significant contraction (, black and red symbols), between −1 and −2% (), whereas the c*-axes, corresponding to the 001 lattice plane distance, expands upon cooling (, blue symbols) or only shows minor contraction for the Br phase (). For all phases, except the chloride phase, the b-axis shows a higher contraction upon cooling than the a-axis. In the F/OH-substituted phase, this trend is more pronounced than in the pure OH-substituted yqt-type ZIF (a,b). The thermal expansion of the Br-substituted phase reflects the pseudo-trigonal lattice symmetry, as the a- and b-axes show an almost identical expansion behavior. In addition, this phase exhibits the smallest overall thermal expansion (). The expansion of the chloride-substituted phase, however, is outstanding, as it shows the highest volume expansion (), the most pronounced anisotropic thermal expansion with the highest expansion of the c*-axis and the largest contraction of the a-axis upon cooling and a nonlinear thermal behavior of the a-axis (c).
cln_elements.clean_text: However, it should be noted that the aforementioned reasons do not exclude a very slowly occurring first-order phase transition between α- and β-Zn3mim5Cl. Interestingly, the transition between an α- and a β-form was only observed for the chloride phase. The fluoride-, hydroxide-, or the bromide-substituted, anhydrous yqt-type ZIF does not exhibit an α-β-transition between 120 and 498 K (Supporting Information Figures S15 and S16). This may be explained by the size and charge density of the inorganic anion: While fluoride and hydroxide seem too small to fill the void within the interpenetrated tfa networks with a linear Zn-X-Zn bridge, chloride has the proper size for a linear bridge. Nevertheless, due to their electronic configuration, these anions still prefer a tetrahedral coordination sphere (Supporting Information, Figure S19), which could be the driving force of the α-β-phase transition. In contrast, bromide is large and has a significantly lower charge density, which allows an almost linear, symmetrical Zn-Br-Zn bridge () and directs the lattice toward trigonal pseudo-symmetry. The Zn-Br bond shows enough flexibility to allow for a monoclinic distortion. The temperature-dependent expansion and contraction of the lattice parameters, which was monitored during heating and cooling cycles between 120 and 498 K (, filled and empty symbols), show anisotropic behavior for all investigated compounds. Upon cooling, both the a- and b-axes show significant contraction (, black and red symbols), between -1 and -2% (), whereas the c*-axes, corresponding to the 001 lattice plane distance, expands upon cooling (, blue symbols) or only shows minor contraction for the Br phase (). For all phases, except the chloride phase, the b-axis shows a higher contraction upon cooling than the a-axis. In the F/OH-substituted phase, this trend is more pronounced than in the pure OH-substituted yqt-type ZIF (a,b). The thermal expansion of the Br-substituted phase reflects the pseudo-trigonal lattice symmetry, as the a- and b-axes show an almost identical expansion behavior. In addition, this phase exhibits the smallest overall thermal expansion (). The expansion of the chloride-substituted phase, however, is outstanding, as it shows the highest volume expansion (), the most pronounced anisotropic thermal expansion with the highest expansion of the c*-axis and the largest contraction of the a-axis upon cooling and a nonlinear thermal behavior of the a-axis (c).

meta.name: fluoride-, hydroxide-, or the bromide-substituted, anhydrous yqt-type ZIF
